Description: When countries like Saudi Arabia and Russia cut oil production, the global supply tightens. Even if the U.S. produces plenty, Americans still pay more at the pump.
Drivers: Saudi Arabia policy, Russian cooperation, demand forecasts
Links: Refineries, Market Speculation, Dollar Strength

Description: Sanctions and supply disruptions forced Europe to replace Russian energy with U.S. oil and gas, creating ripple effects that raised global and domestic prices.
Drivers: Sanctions, pipeline closures, LNG demand shift
Links: LNG Exports, European demand, Grid stability

Description: Exporting natural gas strengthens U.S. geopolitical standing but ties domestic gas prices to global markets, raising winter heating costs at home.
Drivers: Export capacity, Asian/European demand, shipping rates
Links: Ukraine War, China Demand, Pipeline Limits

Description: Because oil is priced in dollars, shifts in U.S. currency values affect both export competitiveness and import costs for energy-related materials.
Drivers: Fed policy, inflation, global trade flows
Links: OPEC+ Cuts, Import costs

Description: When China's economy surges, global oil and gas demand spikes, and U.S. consumers feel the effect.
Drivers: Economic growth, COVID policies, industrial output
Links: LNG Exports, OPEC+ Cuts, Shipping

Description: No major new refineries have been built since the 1970s, and several have closed. Even if crude oil is plentiful, limited refining means higher gasoline and diesel prices.
Drivers: Environmental regulations, capital costs, demand uncertainty
Links: OPEC+ Cuts, Maintenance, Environmental rules

Description: The U.S. electric grid needs massive upgrades to stay reliable and integrate renewables. Fixes cost billions, and utilities pass those costs on to consumers.
Drivers: Deferred maintenance, renewable integration, demand growth
Links: Extreme Weather, Renewable Mandates, Cybersecurity

Description: Insufficient pipelines mean natural gas can't reach some regions cheaply. That's why heating bills in New England can be far higher than in Texas.
Drivers: Permitting delays, NIMBY opposition, environmental concerns
Links: LNG Exports, Permit Delays, State Conflicts

Description: The specialized transformers that power substations have multi-year wait times. Delays make the grid more fragile and expensive to upgrade.
Drivers: Supply chain issues, specialized manufacturing, raw materials
Links: Grid upgrades, Extreme Weather, Import dependencies

Description: During years of low prices, companies postponed repairs. Now, those deferred costs are coming due all at once.
Drivers: 2014-2020 oil bust, aging infrastructure, labor shortage
Links: Labor Shortage, Investment, Safety regulations

Description: Building a pipeline, transmission line, or power plant can take years of review and lawsuits. Supply lags behind demand.
Drivers: Environmental reviews, litigation, federal/state conflicts
Links: Pipeline Limits, Grid upgrades, Renewable projects

Description: As we build renewables, we still have to run fossil fuel plants for backup. Paying for two systems at once drives up rates during the transition.
Drivers: Backup requirements, grid integration, stranded assets
Links: Renewable Mandates, Grid costs, Reliability needs

Description: Each state sets different standards for renewables, reliability, and carbon emissions. This patchwork makes interstate energy trading less efficient and more expensive.
Drivers: RPS standards, pipeline bans, grid rules, carbon policies
Links: Pipeline Limits, Renewable Mandates, Trading barriers

Description: Federal and state carbon rules add compliance costs, making older fossil fuel plants more expensive to operate.
Drivers: EPA rules, state programs, investor pressure
Links: Stranded Assets, Investment uncertainty, Coal retirements

Description: State renewable portfolio standards require specific energy mixes. Integrating them reliably can add costs for storage and grid upgrades.
Drivers: State policies, technology costs, grid integration
Links: Dual System Costs, Grid upgrades, Storage needs

Description: From oilfield workers to nuclear engineers to wind technicians, there aren't enough skilled people. Companies raise wages to compete, and costs get passed down.
Drivers: Aging workforce, skills mismatch, competition from tech
Links: Wages, Maintenance delays, Project timelines

Description: Steel for pipelines, concrete for plants, rare earths for turbines, polysilicon for solar panels — all more expensive. These costs show up in utility bills.
Drivers: Inflation, supply chains, raw material costs
Links: All infrastructure projects, Maintenance

Description: After attacks like the Colonial Pipeline hack, utilities spend heavily on cyber and physical security, adding to overhead.
Drivers: Nation-state actors, ransomware, critical infrastructure risks
Links: Insurance Costs, Grid reliability, Pipeline operations

Description: Inflation and competition from other sectors mean paychecks are growing across the energy industry, raising project and maintenance costs.
Drivers: Labor shortage, inflation, union negotiations
Links: Labor Shortage, Skills Gap, Union contracts

Description: Advanced technologies need specialized training. The lag in workforce development slows projects and raises expenses.
Drivers: Technology changes, training lag, workforce transitions
Links: Labor Shortage, New technologies, Safety issues

Description: Many states rely on a single regulated utility, with guaranteed returns that can encourage spending rather than efficiency.
Drivers: Rate structures, guaranteed returns, regulatory capture
Links: Rate structures, Infrastructure spending, Regulatory policies

Description: Hedge funds and traders betting on oil and gas amplify volatility. Consumers end up feeling price swings disconnected from actual supply.
Drivers: Hedge funds, commodity markets, algorithmic trading
Links: OPEC decisions, Weather events, Supply disruptions

Description: Fewer refineries, pipeline operators, and distributors mean less competition and more pricing power.
Drivers: M&A activity, market power, barriers to entry
Links: Refinery capacity, Pipeline control, Market power

Description: After the 2014–2020 oil bust, shareholders pushed energy companies to prioritize profits over expansion. That means production doesn't ramp up quickly, even when prices spike. Years of cutting corners during low-price eras also left infrastructure weak, requiring costly upgrades now.
Drivers: Investor caution, ESG pressure, capital discipline
Links: Grid, Pipelines, Refinery capacity, Production

Description: Investors worry fossil fuel plants or pipelines will be shut down early by climate policy. To protect themselves, they demand higher returns, making projects more expensive.
Drivers: Climate policies, technology change, investor concerns
Links: Carbon Rules, Investment decisions, Risk premiums

Description: Hurricanes shut refineries, freezes choke gas supplies, heat waves strain the grid. Every major event spikes prices regionally or nationally.
Drivers: Climate change, infrastructure vulnerability, peak demand
Links: Grid failures, Refinery shutdowns, Insurance

Description: The gap between winter heating bills and summer cooling bills is widening, forcing utilities to build expensive backup systems.
Drivers: Weather volatility, peak demand, storage limits
Links: Cooling Demand, Heating needs, Grid stress

Description: Hydropower and water-cooled power plants struggle in dry years, reducing supply and raising prices.
Drivers: Climate patterns, water rights, competing uses
Links: Cooling Demand, Nuclear operations, Agriculture competition

Description: Insuring energy infrastructure in storm- and fire-prone areas is skyrocketing. Utilities pass those premiums into rates.
Drivers: Natural disasters, reinsurance markets, risk models
Links: Extreme Weather, Coastal facilities, Cyber risks

Description: As populations grow in hotter regions, summer demand for air conditioning pushes grids to the limit and drives seasonal price hikes.
Drivers: Population growth in hot areas, heat waves, building stock
Links: Population shifts, Grid capacity, Peak pricing
